result.title: Objective
result.description: To transform the Ukrainian market towards efficient lighting technologies and the phase-out of inefficient lighting

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Estimated amount of energy saved and corresponding GHG reductions attained due to the Project activities.

baseline.comment: Approximately 26.04 TWh/yr of electricity consumed predominantly by incandesced bulbs (IB)

target.comment: To reduce power consumption to 21.08 TWh/yr by phasing-out of IB and replacing thereof with EE Technologies

actual.comment: The Project moves towards the completing of overall objective as the annual power consumption of IB is 20.60 TWh/yr based on the independent study of RBC group. However this reduction caused not only by the Project activties and market factors but also by the hostilities at the Eastern Ukraine as well as by special status of Cremea.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Improve the National policy framework for promoting EE lighting

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Adoption of new legislation promoting EE lighting technologies

baseline.comment: Current legislation

target.comment: National Road-Map for Ukrainian market transition over to EE lighting has been accepted by the Government

actual.comment:
National Road-map for EE lighting market transformation was created and endorsed by public representatives at International conference "Development Of Energy-Efficient Lighting Market In Ukraine: Current status and prospects".
Draft law providing for the phase-out of incandescent bulbs has been duly prepared. Draft law and technical regulation for disposal of CFLs have been developed.
New sanitary and hygienic (health and safety) requirements covering LED have been duly prepared.
A Study of legal relations covering consumer protection to ensure the quality of electricity supplied was conducted. The Project has engaged two experts to support the implementation of the Road-Map for energy inefficient bulbs phase-out from the Ukrainian market

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Improved Quality-Assurance & Quality Control systems for imported and produced lighting products in Ukraine

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Decline of supply/availability of sub-standard EE lighting products in Ukraine
Improvement of product quality/price ratios (i.e. product life, lumens, spectral output, etc.)

baseline.comment: ?o be established by project through sampling; product supply statistics [WHY DONT WE HAVE THIS?]

target.comment: Increased standards for EE lighting products available on the market; decreased quantities of poor quality (“grey”) lighting products available on the market [NEEDS NUMBERS]

actual.comment:
Large-scale Assessment of quality of household EE light sources as well as large-scale Assessment of quality of street light sources were conducted. These studies will help to see the real picture of Ukrainian lighting market including the share of "grey" ligthing sources. The results of the studies will be used to strengthen customs policy of Ukraine.
Large-scale Assessment of quality of office light sources has been commenced in March 2015. Results are expected by September 2015. The summarized results of all abovementioned assessments will be presented at the conference on 22-24 October 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: A new municipal system for CFL collection, recycling, and/or disposal has been launched.

baseline.comment: Current unavailability of adequate and orderly operating system

target.comment: Locally adapted sustainable system developed based on the international best practice

actual.comment:
The traditional conference on the strategy of disposal of mercury containing light sources in Ukraine was held in October 2014. There was more than 200 participants. The main objective of the conference was to conduct public and professional hearings on new legislation on waste handling. In particular the TMEL Project presented the developed strategy, technical regulation and law on utilization of household CFLs that were endorsed in resolution of the Conference.
The pilot project for disposal of CFLs was completed, and results thereof have been applied to develop the CFL disposal system used in several nationwide supermarket chains. The Project targeted 7 cities throughout Ukraine and was focused on exchange of used CFLs for the discount to buy a new one. During one month approximately 44 000 of CFLs were disposed by mobile disposal factory. Also the dedicated materials covering disposal of CFLs have been developed and disseminated among the retail store networks .

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Implement efficient lighting demonstrations in municipal educational sector

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Estimated amounts of energy saved and corresponding GHG reductions attained due to the Project activities.

baseline.comment:
Baseline for each project is calculated based on the initial consumption and equipment initially used. The baseline calculations has been done based on consultations with relevant experts/energy audit companies.
Approximately 26.04 TWh/yr of electricity consumed predominantly using incandesced bulbs

target.comment: Lighting systems of 50 project sites/facilities in 7 municipalities to be duly upgraded with EE lighting

actual.comment: There are 11 Pilots in 8 municipalities as of 30 June 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of successfully completed projects for upgrading/complete overhaul of lighting systems.

baseline.comment: Baselines for energy-savings will need to be established during the project for participating institutions.

target.comment: Sites/locations/facilities in at least 7 municipalities have been duly upgraded with EE lighting systems.

actual.comment: There are 11 Pilots implemented by 30 June. The Project has held a tender for purchase of up-to-date street, office and household EE light sources in order to distribute thereof among 9 municipalities on competitive basis in the second half of 2015. The total numbers of purchased bulbs are: 5000 of HSVLs, 4000 LEDs, 3000 CFLs.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Improve EE Lighting product penetration in the Residential Sector

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1) Residential EE lighting products sales uplift due to the Project activities

baseline.comment: Ukrainian market current statistics stating EE light products sales uplift

target.comment: EE lighting products/equipment annualized market growth rate is doubled equaling to 20% (currently 10-15%)

actual.comment:
The annualized EEL market growth rate in the reporting period was 19% according to the assessment done by the expert on GHG emissions reduction.
ALL-UKRAINIAN PUBLIC AWARENESS PROMOTIONAL CAMPAIGN ON ENERGY EFFICIENT LIGHTING (PHASE 2) has been launched in summer 2015 and to be completed in winter 2015-2016. The Phase 2 of the Campaign is focused on rural and recreational areas which were not covered by Phase 1. The campaign includes presentation of specially developed features (scientific movie and cartoon) on Ukrainian TV (25 regional and 7 national channels). According to estimations this will allow to increase the demand on EEL by 23%.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2) Energy savings gained using CFLs disseminated by the Project.

baseline.comment: (not given)

target.comment: To disseminate at least 40 million additional EE lighting products within the residential sector

actual.comment:
0,8 TWh/yr owning to indirect activities for the reporting period or cumulative 1,8 TWh.
3,6MW/yr owning to pilot projects completed for the reporting period or cumulative 4,1MWh.

result.title: Outcome 5
result.description: Dissemination and Replication of the Project Results

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Information publications & training workshops for municipality staff.

baseline.comment: Quite a number of various publications on EE Lighting is available, however quite a few describe successful projects implemented in Ukraine.

target.comment:
At least 2 information publications for municipalities.
At least 10 training workshops provided for different municipalities not previously covered by this project.

actual.comment:
The International conference "DEVELOPMENT OF ENERGY-EFFICIENT LIGHTING MARKET IN UKRAINE: CURRENT STATUS AND PROSPECTS" was held in November 2014. It was dedicated to the Project progress and plans on 2015 year also it was the framework to endorse by public the developed Road-Map and laws.
Guidebook on EE lighting has been elaborated, and it is currently planned to be integrated into Ukrainian Universities’ Curricula for technical specialties (ecological bias) and environmental specialties (technical and economic bias).
The book on implementation of energy efficient streetligthing for municipalities is produced and is currently planned to be disseminated among all municipalities of Ukraine.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Expansion/replication of the EE lighting projects in new municipalities.

baseline.comment: (not given)

target.comment: Expansion/replication of the EE lighting projects in 20 new municipalities.

actual.comment: In total 5 municipalities follow the project experience by the end of this reporting period. These include two new municipalities of Slavutich and Dniprodzerzhinsk that have started the process of redevelopment and reorganization of their EE street lighting using the project`s expertise.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: New EE lighting projects co-funded using carbon finance procedures

baseline.comment: Currently no EE lighting projects in Ukraine have been started using JI & carbon finance.

target.comment: (not given)

actual.comment: Currently there are no new EE lighting projects co-funded using carbon finance procedures

iati-activity.title: Conservation and Sustainable Use of Peatlands
iati-activity.description: The project will demonstrate how within one landscape certain areas of abandoned degraded agricultural peatlands that emit carbon can be restored, while adjacent areas can be protected at the same time to increase carbon sequestration.

iati-activity.title: Peatland restoration
iati-activity.description: The project objective is to create a model for restoration of drained degraded peatlands that emit carbon, to produce cost-efficient positive effect both on climate change mitigation and adaptation, ecosystem’s health and local economy.

iati-activity.title: Rio Conventions in National Policies
iati-activity.description: Integrating Rio Convention Provisions into Ukraine's National Policy Framework

iati-activity.title: Rio Conventions in Policies
iati-activity.description: Ukraine's implementation of the three Rio Conventions on a strengthened policy and institutionally sustainable development baseline is catalyzed.

location.name: Kyiv
location.activity-description: Policy and outreach

result.title: Objective
result.description: A. To integrate principles and obligations of the three Rio Conventions into Ukraine's national policy framework B. To strengthen key institutional and individual capacities to implement policies, plans, and programmes that deliver global environmental benefits

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Rio Convention obligations are an integral part of the Sustainable Development Strategy
SDS Roadmap is an overarching plan of action for the environmental and sectoral action plans
The Government of Ukraine and a wide range of stakeholders systematically review natural resource and environmental policies in a holistic manner in line with Rio Conventions requirements.
Recommended reforms and restructuring per the SDS are presented for parliamentary consideration

baseline.comment:
There is no overarching policy that links the Rio Conventions w/in the framework of national sustainable development
Requirements of the Rio Conventions are not effectively integrated into sectoral legislation
There is little inter-ministerial coordination on the implementation of natural resource and environmental policies.
Policy interventions often result in overlap, duplication of effort, and weak implementation.
There is limited stakeholder involvement in the consultative process that informs policy-making.

target.comment:
A draft Sustainable Development Strategy has been approved by the Cabinet of Ministers and ready for Parliamentary consideration for adoption
A draft SDS Roadmap has been approved by the Cabinet of Ministers
There is a minimum of 20% increase in the understanding of the Rio Convention mainstreaming among government staff
There is a minimum of 15% increase in the appreciation of the Rio Conventions among the general public
There is a minimum of 25% increase in the acceptance by government representatives and other stakeholder representatives of the legitimacy of the SDS and its accompanying Roadmap

actual.comment:
- Almost all national stakeholders (target ministries, in particular) demonstrate political will to review the current policies and align them with the Sustainable Development concept, international obligations. This is especially topical for Ukraine now, in the view of the country’s commitment to approximate its legislative and normative frameworks to the EU requirements.
- Non-governmental partners stay actively involved in the project and stand ready to support further activities, specifically on the way to develop the Sustainable Development Strategy (SDS) based on evidences and best practices from the neighboring European countries
- The project is actively promoting knowledge and hands-on examples of implementation of the Rio Conventions among the key stakeholders

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Policies and institutions catalyze the mainstreaming of the Rio Convention principles and obligations into sectoral policies

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
1.1
SWOT and Gap analysis of Ukraine's policy framework and institutional implementation of Rio Conventions
Analytical framework report for Rio Convention mainstreaming
Eight (8) sectoral analytical reports containing detailing opportunities for mainstreaming Rio Conventions
At least 10 peer review comments submitted for each sectoral analysis
High quality rating of all eight completed sectoral analyses rated by peer review experts
Each constituent public dialogue/ council is attended by at least 50 diverse representatives from the target stakeholder constituency

baseline.comment:
2007 NCSA Thematic and Cross-Cutting Assessments
Sectoral assessments undertaken for specific ministries
Relevant assessments and analyses are no longer current due to policy and institutional changes in the past year and the October 2012 elections

target.comment:
At least 50 experts agree to be peer reviewers by month 3 .
An inventory of action plans to implement Rio Conventions and sectoral programmes is prepared by month 3
Analytical framework for Rio Convention mainstreaming completed by month 6
Eight (8) SWOT and Gap analyses on the selected eight sectors drafted by month 8
Analyses made widely available to all stakeholders w/in 4 weeks of their completion
Four public stakeholder constituent meetings held by month 10 to review sectoral reports

actual.comment:
Eight (8) comprehensive SWOT and Gap analyses of legislation in 8 sectors were completed to identify existing gaps in meeting the provisions of the Rio Conventions.
At least 90 experts acted as peers reviewers for the reports and deemed the recommendations relevant and feasible.
The ministries hosted 7 round tables where the reports were presented and specific recommendations provided by UNDP experts.
Wide stakeholder engagement was ensured through the all-inclusive consultative process, including public discussion platforms (with policy makers, academia, NGOs, private sector)

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
1.2:
Draft Sustainable Development Strategy articulates a holistic vision and programmatic approach to policy and legislative reforms that catalyze Rio Convention implementation
Draft SDS is prepared
Key stakeholders actively participated in the drafting of the integrated SDS
Assessment report of guidelines, tools, and resources to facilitate implementation of sectoral policies, plans, and programmes and legislation
Official Endorsement of recommended policy and legislative reforms by independent experts, decision-makers, and key stakeholder representatives
At least 20 peer review comments submitted from diverse independent experts
High quality rating of draft SDS by peer review experts

baseline.comment:
Environmental legislation is extensive but not cohesive and sometimes conflict with other legislation
Rio Conventions obligations are not effectively integrated within national legislation
Commitment to Rio Convention provisions are not evident
A draft of the SDS exists, but does not fully integrate Rio Convention provisions
The draft SDS was not carried out to sufficiently engage and secure endorsement of all key stakeholders
Draft SDS, though considered by the Cabinet of Ministers, was not considered by Parliament

target.comment:
Two expert workshops are convened to draft the SDS between months 12 and 17
Draft SDS that provides a vision for mainstreaming Rio Conventions into sectoral policies, plans, programmes and legislation completed by the NASU by month 18
Annotated outline of guidelines, tools and resources for SDS implementation completed by month 18
Four public stakeholder constituent meetings on the draft SDS held by month 19
SDS concept prepared and submitted for parliamentary consideration by month 22

actual.comment:
The project initiated public discussions with the same key target groups - policy makers, academia, NGOs, private sector - on the development of the Sustainable Development Strategy (SDS), with the aim to strengthen Ukraine's environmental governance. The parties express their commitment to contribute to the development of the SDS.
The project is contracting a group of experts to draft the SDS and coordinate stakeholders’ engagement
The project’s ongoing interventions (studies, round tables, presentations) are fueling policy and legislative reforms that result in cross-sectoral integration of the Rio Conventions provisions.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Capacities developed to implement Rio Conventions through national and regional SDS implementation

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
2.1:
Learn-by-doing mainstreaming of Rio Conventions into selected sectoral policies, plans, programmes, and legislation at the regional, national, and local levels
Four sets of high priority Rio Convention mainstreaming recommendations from the eight sectoral analyses are selected for targeted implementation at the regional, national, and local levels
All selected Rio Convention mainstreaming recommendations are completed within a 12 month period
Independent evaluation of targeted mainstreaming activities, best practices, and lessons learned

baseline.comment: Current programmes for regional economic development are not sustainable and do not adequately take into account national or international environmental priorities or obligations

target.comment:
Rio Convention awareness survey of ministry and agency staff completed with N200 respondents by month 3
Statistical analysis of survey results completed month 5
Assessment of training needs assessment report completed by month 9
Four (4) high priority recommendations, one each from the sectoral analyses, selected for early implementation by month 10
Training programme on selected sectoral mainstreaming activities is drafted, peer reviewed, and approved by month 13
Four (4) sets of Rio Convention mainstreaming activities under implementation at the regional or local level by month 14 and completed by month 19
Lessons learned and best practice report prepared on targeted regional Rio Convention mainstreaming activities completed by month 21

actual.comment:
The civil servants’ knowledge gaps with respect to the Rio Conventions and SD principles were identified via a targeted survey. The training needs assessment revealed a lack of understanding of the linkages between specific policies of various ministries and their environmental impacts, and helped determine the specific needs to be addressed by the project. The survey has served as a baseline for the development of educational module and a textbook for the civil servants.
Capacities of relevant decision makers are enhanced through a series of educational initiatives: national conference on public governance for Sustainable Development (180 attendees), workshops and summer school for civil servants (more than 80 attendees)
Four targeted mainstreaming activities are underway - they are focusing on: 1. Promotion of sustainable (green) business practices; 2. Popularize sustainable consumption ideas (e.g. minimize resource use, consume eco-friendly goods and reduce waste); 3. Promotion of knowledge of sustainable development among the general public via the online educational course from a recognized university; via setting up an informational hub on SD in the botanic garden (central park, Kyiv). All four initiatives will have an essential coverage and possibility for replication

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
2.2: Draft SDS Roadmap for the effective integration and institutionalization of Rio Convention provisions into sectoral policies, plans, programmes, and legislation
Draft SDS Roadmap document is prepared
SMART indicators to measure SDS Roadmap implementation are developed
Specific structures and arrangements for national SDS implementation are recommended for regional and central government consideration
At least 20 peer review comments submitted from diverse independent experts
High quality rating of draft SDS Roadmap by peer review experts

baseline.comment:
There is no systematic approach or institutional procedures to integrate environmental conservation priorities and Rio Convention provisions into socio-economic development planning processes
There is no coordination among agencies and ministries to reconcile design and implementation of sectoral plans with Rio Convention provisions
There are a number of donor-funded projects that have and are supporting environmental mainstreaming to conform with EU standards, but a small fraction deal with the Rio Conventions

target.comment:
Preliminary public administration training programme approved by month 9
Comprehensive public administration training programme approved by month 20
Draft SDS roadmap is completed by month 22
At least 50 representatives from the main stakeholder constituencies actively consulted on the draft roadmap
Draft SDS roadmap is endorsed and validated by a consensus of key stakeholder representatives by month 23
Draft SDS roadmap is considered by Cabinet of Ministers and Parliamentarians by month 26

actual.comment:
The training course and a textbook on sustainable development is being finalized and almost ready for printing. It will be launched at the National Academy of Public Administration by the President of Ukraine in October 2015;
The project is working on two brochures that will serve as methodological guidance for all parties who will be involved in the SDS development and implementation (translation and re-printing of IISD/GIZ and OECD/UNDP books on the development of SDS are underway).

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Enhanced awareness and understanding of the environment's contribution to socio-economic development, with particular reference to the Rio Conventions

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
3.1: Kick-Off Conference
One-day Kick-Off Conference raises high profile of Rio Convention mainstreaming into sectoral policies, plans, programmes, and legislation through a series of eight (8) sectoral panel discussions

baseline.comment: As a follow-up to Rio+20, Ukraine will be organizing an annual conference to promote national action to its follow-up. However, this will likely take place before this project can be included among the activities. Also, a separate conference would give a higher profile of the need for Rio Convention mainstreaming. A half-day special event will be organized during the Rio+20 Conference to promote the project (non-GEF funds)

target.comment:
One-day Kick-Off Conference is held by month 3
Eight (8) expert panel discussions present the value of Rio Convention mainstreaming (Concurrent panel discussions)
Over 240 participants attend the Kick-Off Conference
At least 30 participants attend each of the panel discussions

actual.comment: The conference gathered at least 150 major stakeholders on 3 July 2014 and briefed them on the project goals and activities to increase awareness on Rio Conventions and encourage their applications to each targeted sector. The panel discussions were organized around each convention

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
3.2: Broad-based survey on public awareness
Analysis of the Ukraine's awareness and understanding of the link between environment and development (report)
Improved awareness and understanding of the value of mainstreaming Rio Conventions within sectoral policies, plans, programmes and legislation

baseline.comment:
Awareness and understanding of the Rio Conventions have improved in the past year as a result of Rio+20. However, environmental issues in the Ukraine remain to be seen as a separate sector, with marginal policy influence on socio-economic development priorities
The most recent relevant survey on Ukraine’s environmental attitudes and values was taken in 2005. While it provided useful data, in the advent of Rio+20 this data is out of date.

target.comment:
Two broad-based surveys are carried out, the first by month 3 and the second by month 30
At least 500 survey respondents participate in the survey
Statistical and sociological analyses (2x) of survey results completed by month 5 (baseline) and month 32

actual.comment: The initial broad-based survey was carried out in September 2014 among at least 1200 respondents. The results were analyzed and presented in the report describing key gaps and suggesting key topics for subsequent information campaigns (the report is being printed and will be distributed among stakeholders), and available at UNDP and partners’ websites

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
3.3: Public awareness campaign
Comprehensive public awareness plan developed to detail the content and distribution of materials and media

baseline.comment: In the past year, Ukraine has been carrying out a number of activities to promote environmental consciousness in conjunction with Rio+20, among other MEAs. However, these have focused on specific thematic issues

target.comment:
Programme of work on public awareness and advocacy activities developed in cooperation with partner development agencies completed by month 4
Suite of public awareness activities underway by month 5

actual.comment:
The project’s communications plan is developed
The project regularly posts news in the social media, UNDP website, governmental and other partner websites

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description:
Output 3.4:
Public awareness and educational materials
Articles on Rio Convention mainstreaming in popular literature
High school competitions on links between local behaviour and the global environment
High school education modules and accompanying lecture material on the global environment

baseline.comment:
Articles on the Rio Conventions are being published, but in specialized literature that is largely read by environmental supporters or in the popular literature during crisis events, with few exceptions
Only some high schools currently teach environmental issues once a week, with limited content

target.comment:
At least 18 articles on Rio Convention mainstreaming published in popular literature with high circulation, at least one every 2 months, the first by month 3
Articles on Rio Convention mainstreaming are also published as brochures, at 100 copies each, and distributed to at least two high value special events, at least 9 by month 20 and at least 18 by month 32
Project plan for high school competitions on Rio Convention mainstreaming completed by month 8
High school education module on Rio Conventions and accompanying lecture material are completed by month 8
At least 10 high schools carry out Rio Convention mainstreaming competitions and have implemented education module by month 20
At least 20 high schools carry out Rio Convention mainstreaming competitions and have implemented education module by month 32

actual.comment:
In 2014 at least 15 articles were published in the specialized (sector-specific) literature/digests outlining the results of SWOT and Gap analyses
Following the trainings for journalists in 2014, at least 10 articles were published in regional mass media
The regulations on high school competitions are developed. The contest is planned to be announced in 2015
High school educational module is developed. Currently, the project is approaching the Ministry of Education to pilot this module at the selected schools
The project received at least 70 applications/videos from students studying communications/PR in response to the annual national contest of social advertisement among students, in nomination ‘Sustainable Development’
The project co-organized a national contest of professional photography announced by the recognized Ukrainian newspaper ‘Day’. Winners in the category ‘Sustainable Development’ were distinguished by the project at the closing ceremony of the contest

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description:
Output 3.5:
Awareness-raising dialogues and workshops
Media awareness workshops on Rio Convention mainstreaming
Expert panel discussions on synergies between Rio Conventions and business
Annual public constituent meetings on Rio Convention mainstreaming
Regional sensitization of Rio Convention mainstreaming and SDS implementation
Increased sensitization and understanding on Rio Convention mainstreaming values

baseline.comment:
Media professionals generally have no special training or understanding of Rio Convention mainstreaming issues
The private sector is primarily focused on traditional approaches to maximizing profits, seeing environmental issues as an added transaction cost that reduces profits
Public dialogues (national platforms) were recently created to discuss key environmental issues, and set up to meet once a year
Regional government representatives are not familiar with approaches to mainstream Rio Convention into regional development
The general public in Ukraine remains generally unaware or unconcerned about the contribution of the Rio Conventions to meeting and satisfying local and national socio-economic priorities

target.comment:
At least five (5) media awareness workshops held, each with at least 20 participating media representatives, the first by month 6
Three (3) panel discussions, with at least 50 private sector representatives, one held each year, the first by month 7
At least four regional awareness workshops on Rio Convention mainstreaming and SDS implementation held by month 29, with at least 50 regional government representatives attending each
Four (4) public dialogues meetings carried out in year 3 by month 32
By month 32, statistical and sociological analysis of broad-based survey shows at least 20% increase in the understanding of Rio Convention mainstreaming values and opportunities
By month 32, reporting in the popular literature on Rio Convention mainstreaming shows a 10% increase over business as usual forecast

actual.comment:
Trainings for journalists (twice in 2014, each attended at least by 20 journalists), public platforms – (four in 2015 – targeting business, NGOs, policy makers, NGOs, at least 50 attendees each one)
Major public events organized in 2014 included: Inception Workshop; Kick-Off Conference, National Conference on Public Administration and SD

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description:
Output 3.6:
Training of government staff on Rio Convention mainstreaming
Comprehensive training programme on Rio Convention mainstreaming integrated within National Academy of Public Administration (NAPU) trainings
Number of government staff and stakeholder representatives that participated actively in learn-by doing Rio Convention mainstreaming through activities 1.2.1, 1.2.2, 2.1.3, 2.1.4, 2.1.5, and 3.3.1
SDS training workshops carried out at the regional and national levels
Rio Convention Focal Points endorse SDS implementation

baseline.comment:
Low awareness and understanding of government staff on the importance of Rio Conventions to national socio-economic priorities
National Academy of Public Administration provides advanced for government staff, but presently does not include Rio Convention mainstreaming

target.comment:
Comprehensive training programme is completed by month 22 and approved for integration into NAPU’s training programme by month 26
Learn-by-doing activities of activities 1.2.1, 1.2.2, 2.1.3, 2.1.4, 2.1.5, and 3.3.1:
Preparation of draft SDS Roadmap (activities 1.2.1 and 1.2.2)
Structuring of 8 regional Rio Convention mainstreaming priority actions under the sectoral analyses (activity 2.1.3)
? Preparation of targeted training project (activity 2.1.4)
? Active participation in targeted regional Rio Convention mainstreaming exercises (activity 2.1.5) and preparation of public awareness campaign (activity 3.3.1)
? All Rio Convention Focal Points endorse SDS and accompanying roadmap for Parliamentary ap

actual.comment:
Assessment of baseline knowledge of 140 civil servants was conducted in 2014.
In addition to the training module to be launched as per item 2.2, there is an agreement with the National Academy of Public Administration to co-organize regional educational workshops for civil servants

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description:
Output 3.7:
Internet visibility of Rio Convention mainstreaming
Website promotes Rio Convention mainstreaming
Facebook page on Rio Convention mainstreaming

baseline.comment: Environment for Ukraine is a current website that is devoted to promoting environmental issues, but does not include information that promotes the linkage between Rio Conventions and socio-economic development

target.comment:
Environment for Ukraine website includes new webpage and introductory articles on Rio Convention mainstreaming by month 3
Website is regularly updated, at least once a month with new information, articles, and relevant links on Rio Convention mainstreaming.
Number of visits to the Rio Convention mainstreaming webpages raises sustained visits to Environment for Ukraine website by at least 10%.
Facebook page created by month 3
At least 3,000 Facebook likes by month 32

actual.comment:
The project’s website is developed and being filled with the content: http://sd4ua.org/
The Facebook page is updated on the daily basis: www.facebook.com/bioundp

iati-activity.title: Bioenergy Technologies
iati-activity.description: Development and Commercialization of Bioenergy Technologies in the Municipal Sector of Ukraine

iati-activity.title: Bioenergy Technologies
iati-activity.description: GHG emissions are reduced by promoting utilisation of agricultural biomass potential for municipal heat and hot water services

country-budget-items.budget-item: Energy - power generation

transaction.disbursement-channel: Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account

result.title: Objective
result.description: The objective of the project is to significantly increase the use of biomass energy as a fuel source for heating and hot water services in the municipal sector in Ukraine by at least 20% over the baseline scenario in order to reduce direct greenhouse gas emissions by 63,577 tons of CO2 over the 4-year life of the project and, subsequently, 19,143 tons of CO2 during each year of the remaining 16-year life of the boiler equipment. When one looks at the 20 year lifetime of the boilers earmarked for development during the project period, the boilers will have generated 1,618,834 MWhTH, with a combined amount of CO2 reduced of 361,000 tons, equivalent to $13 of GEF funds per tCO2.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Municipalities/ Private Sector have operationalised direct investment in municipal biomass projects for heat and hot water supply.

baseline.comment:
GHG in the municipal heating sector scheduled to increase from 434.4 million tCO2 (in 2005, as per Ukraine’s Third, Fourth and Fifth National Communications to UNFCCC prepared in 2009 (all three issued in one document)) to as high as 740.7 million tCO2 by 2030.The present contribution of biomass towards heat/hot water supply is estimated at 75 GWhTH.
Negligible investments taking place in municipal biomass for heat and hot water supply.

target.comment:
285 GWhTH in terms of heat and hot water generated (as a result of the 18 municipal biomass systems brought on-line) by project completion.
Direct reduction of 63,577 tons of CO2 over the 4-year FSP project life cycle and 361,000 over the full lifetime of the plants.
Estimated cumulative indirect GHG emission reduction of over 1.4 million tons of CO2 by 2035 on the basis of a conservative policy scenario and a GEF causality factor of 80%.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description:
Streamlined and comprehensive market-oriented policy and legal/regulatory framework to promote municipal biomass for heat and hot water services.
Municipal Targets for Biomass Energy for heating are agreed and established.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Policy and legal/regulatory framework finalized, adopted and available for consultation by potential investors.
Confirmation that municipal targets have been established.

baseline.comment:
None available at the present time.
None available at the present time.

target.comment:
To be completed within 15 months of recruitment of project manager and approved by Government 1.5 years after start of project.
To be completed within 12 months of project start.

actual.comment: The policy and legal/regulatory framework review has started. Key partner oblasts and municipalities selected and approved.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Capacity available within MAPF to support development and implementation of a municipal biomass programme through the establishment of a Biomass Support Unit.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of staff who participated in and successfully completed capacity development programme, including training on the revised and updated Municipal Biomass Guide.

baseline.comment: None available at the present time.

target.comment: Ten staff trained within 15 months of recruitment of project manager.

actual.comment: Technical knowledge and awareness of biomass utilization practices enhanced among 15 government officials, policy makers and energy professionals through participation in a study tour to Sweden.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Investment promotion in municipal use of biomass through establishment/strengthening of Financial Support Mechanism.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Funding available from DerzhZemBank, including funds under FSM, to support preparation of feasibility studies, business plans and investment.

baseline.comment: Not presently available.

target.comment: Construction of at least 18 municipal biomass projects completed by the end of the project.

actual.comment: Implementation of 2 municipal biomass projects is completed, 5 projects launched.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Outreach programme and dissemination of project experience/best practices/lessons learned for replication throughout the country.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Outreach programme formulated. Project experience compiled, analysed and disseminated.

baseline.comment: Lack of sufficient information to pursue programme.

target.comment: Increased awareness among stakeholders in place to promote and develop the market for municipal biomass.

actual.comment: Development of the National plan for implementing outreach/promotional activities to support biomass projects targeting domestic (and international) investors has started.
